context: In <b5_0>1985<b5_0/>, Spielberg released <b6_0><b7_0>The Color Purple<b7_0/><b6_0/>, an adaptation of <a0_0>Alice Walker<a0_0/>'s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel of the same name, about <a1_0>a generation of empowered African-American women during depression-era America<a1_0/>. Starring <a2_0>Whoopi Goldberg and future talk-show superstar Oprah Winfrey<a2_0/>, the film was a box office smash and critics hailed Spielberg's successful foray into the dramatic genre. Roger Ebert <a3_0>proclaimed it the best film of the year and later entered it into his Great Films archive<a3_0/>. The film received <a4_0>eleven<a4_0/> Academy Award nominations, including two for Goldberg and Winfrey. However, much to the surprise of many, Spielberg did not get a Best Director nomination.
